testTitle: Driving Theory Test - Hazard Perception Focus
testDescription: Advanced driving theory test focusing on hazard perception, road safety, and defensive driving techniques.

questions.stem: When approaching a roundabout, you should:

options.label: Always give way to traffic from the right
Always give way to traffic from the left
Have right of way over all traffic
Only give way to larger vehicles

questions.explanation: At roundabouts in the UK, you must give way to traffic approaching from your right, unless road markings or signs indicate otherwise.

questions.stem: What is the minimum stopping distance for a car traveling at 70 mph in good, dry conditions?
questions.explanation: At 70 mph, the total stopping distance is 96 meters (315 feet), which includes thinking distance (21m) plus braking distance (75m) in dry conditions.

questions.stem: Which of these situations require you to use headlights during daylight hours?

options.label: In fog with visibility below 100 meters

questions.explanation: Headlights must be used in tunnels, during poor weather conditions like heavy rain, and in fog when visibility is seriously reduced.

questions.stem: You should use the left-hand lane of a dual carriageway unless overtaking.
questions.explanation: On dual carriageways and motorways, you should normally use the left-hand lane and only use other lanes for overtaking or when directed by signs.

questions.stem: What does a red triangle warning sign typically indicate?
questions.explanation: Red triangle warning signs alert drivers to hazards ahead such as bends, hills, level crossings, or other potential dangers.

questions.stem: When should you check your mirrors while driving?
questions.explanation: You should regularly check mirrors - before signaling, changing lanes, slowing down, or stopping. This helps maintain awareness of traffic around you.

questions.stem: The speed limit in a built-up area is typically:
questions.explanation: The default speed limit in built-up areas (areas with street lighting) is 30 mph, unless signs indicate otherwise. Some areas may have 20 mph limits.

options.label: When other drivers are using them

questions.explanation: Fog lights should only be used when visibility is seriously reduced (typically less than 100 meters). They must be switched off when conditions improve to avoid dazzling other drivers.

questions.stem: Catalytic converters help reduce harmful emissions from vehicle exhausts.
questions.explanation: Catalytic converters are devices that reduce harmful pollutants in exhaust gases, converting toxic compounds into less harmful emissions.

questions.stem: What should you do if your vehicle breaks down on a motorway?

options.label: Pull onto the hard shoulder if possible
Exit the vehicle from the side away from traffic
Stand behind your vehicle to warn other drivers

questions.explanation: If you break down on a motorway: use the hard shoulder, put on hazard lights, exit away from traffic, and wait in a safe place. Never stand behind your vehicle.

questions.stem: When joining a motorway, you should:

options.label: Use the acceleration lane to build up speed
Stop at the end of the slip road
Force your way into the traffic

questions.explanation: Use the acceleration lane (slip road) to build up to the speed of traffic on the motorway, then merge safely when there's a suitable gap.
Tailgating means following the vehicle in front too closely, which reduces your stopping distance and increases the risk of rear-end collisions.
